text: Biofilm formation explains the persistence of drug-resistant infections, such as those associated with urinary catheters in long-term hospital patients.
The Enterobacteriaceae are Gram-negative rods, although as nutrients diminish, their size dwindles almost to a coccoid form.
They ferment rapidly on carbohydrates, generating fermentation intestine supports the growth of organisms utilizing these gases, including methanogens (discussed in Chapter 19).
forms single-flagellated rods full of sulfur over time (1–5) as a Chromatium isolate oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+.
Most strains grow well with or without oxygen, by either respiration (aerobic or anaerobic) or fermentation.
Many species are motile, with numerous flagella.
They grow singly, in chains, or in biofilms.
feeding on our mucous secretions and producing vitamins, pathogens include Salmonella enterica and Shigella flexneri.
